newsitem.title: MEXICO: Alestra announces Mexico long-distance rates. [CORRECTED 23:58 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Alestra announces Mexico long-distance rates. [CORRECTED 23:58 GMT]

text.p: Alestra, a Mexican long-distance telephone company owned by AT&T Corp and Mexican holding company Grupo Industrial Alfa SA de CV, on Tuesday announced its domestic residential long-distance rates effective January 1, when the Mexican market is opened to competition.

"We have registered rates ... for residential service of 1.65 pesos per minute during the daytime and half of that, 82.5 centavos per minute, during nights and weekends," Jorge Escribiano, Alestra's director of communications, told Reuters.
(Deletes paragraphs, correcting to show Escribiano made no reference to Telmex rates).
Daytime or peak hours will be considered from 0800 to 2000 Monday through Friday, he said.
Telmex, a former state enterprise that was privatized in 1991, will face competition from a host of Mexican and international companies starting in 1997.
